question: The plant body of bryophytes is more ______ than that of algae.
Bryophyte plant body is thallus-like and ______ or erect.
Bryophytes are attached to the substratum by ______ or multicellular rhizoids.
Bryophytes lack true roots, ______ or leaves.
The main plant body of the bryophyte is ______.
The bryophyte gametophyte produces ______.
The sex organs in bryophytes are ______.
The male sex organ in bryophytes is called ______.
Antheridia produce ______ antherozoids.
The female sex organ in bryophytes is called ______.
The archegonium is ______-shaped and produces a single egg.
An antherozoid fuses with the egg to produce a ______.
Zygotes in bryophytes do not undergo reduction division ______.
Zygotes produce a multicellular body called a ______.
The sporophyte is attached to the ______ gametophyte.
The sporophyte derives nourishment from the ______.
Some cells of the sporophyte undergo meiosis to produce ______ spores.
These haploid spores germinate to produce the ______.
Bryophytes have little economic importance but some mosses provide ______ for animals.
Species of ______ provide peat used as fuel and packing material.
Sphagnum is used as packing material because of its capacity to hold ______.
Mosses along with lichens are the first organisms to colonise ______.
Mosses decompose rocks and make the substrate suitable for ______ plants.
Mosses form dense mats on the soil and prevent ______ erosion.
Bryophytes are divided into ______ and mosses.
Liverworts usually grow in moist, ______ habitats.
Liverworts grow on banks of streams, marshy ground, and damp ______.
The liverwort plant body is ______.
An example of a thalloid liverwort is ______.
The liverwort thallus is dorsiventral and closely ______ to the substrate.
Leafy liverworts have leaf-like appendages in ______ rows.
Asexual reproduction in liverworts occurs by fragmentation or ______.
Gemmae are green, multicellular, ______ buds.
Gemmae develop in structures called ______ cups.
Gemma cups are located on the ______.
Gemmae detach from the parent body and ______ into new individuals.
During sexual reproduction, male and female sex organs may be on same or different ______.
The liverwort sporophyte is differentiated into foot, seta and ______.
Spores are produced within the capsule after ______.
These spores germinate to form free-living ______.
Bryophytes are attached to substrate by ______ or multicellular rhizoids.
Bryophytes may possess root-like, stem-like or ______-like structures.
The egg is produced inside the ______.
Biflagellate antherozoids are produced by the ______.
The capsule is part of the liverwort ______.
Marchantia is an example of a ______ liverwort.
Liverworts grow on damp soil, tree bark and in deep ______.
Spores in liverworts are formed inside the ______.
The liverwort thallus is ______ and closely appressed to the substrate.
Sphagnum moss provides ______ used as fuel.
Bryophyte sporophyte remains ______ on the gametophyte.
Liverworts reproduce asexually by ______ or gemmae.
Multicellular rhizoids help attach bryophytes to the ______.
Gemmae are ______ buds that grow into new plants.
Gemmae develop in special ______ called gemma cups.
The liverwort capsule produces spores after ______.
Male and female organs may be present on the same or different ______.
The seta connects the foot and the ______ in the sporophyte.
Bryophytes reproduce sexually through antheridia and ______.
The female reproductive organ in liverworts is the ______.
Bryophyte gametophyte is the main ______ generation.
The sporophyte derives ______ from the gametophyte.
Mosses prevent soil erosion by forming ______ on the soil.
Mosses and lichens are the first organisms to ______ rocks.
The antherozoids reach the archegonium through ______.
The main function of the foot in sporophyte is ______.
Liverworts have tiny leaf-like appendages arranged in ______ rows.
Liverworts can be found on tree ______ in moist environments.
Gemmae develop inside gemma ______ on the thallus.
Archegonium in liverworts produces a single ______.
